reviewText:
I played the game through in a little under 2 hours but I had a bit of a break in between where I had the pause menu open. I would say you could play it through in 1h 30m or maybe less, depending how long it takes you to figure out some of the puzzles.

The game is a very beautiful platformer with a few puzzles here and there. The game is not very hard and when you die you do spawn close by, not having to repeat to much each time.

In this game you control a little Robot who starts it's adventure near a crash site. Without giving to much away, as you progress through the alien world you find audio tapes which have recordings for you from someone who knows you, giving away pieces of a background story about you and your existence with each audio tape.

The story is light but has a bit of a surprise" revelation to it at the end
date:
adding a nice touch.

The game is just beautiful and colorful with an amazing looking alien world and creatures. The different environments you play through are stunning and the atmosphere and music are perfectly balanced.

The game is very short and given you can complete it in under 1.5 hours it is up to you to decide if that is worth a price tag of €9.99.

The game makes up for it in its stunning looks and the amazing experience I had playing it and I know I will play through it again.

For me it was worth it and I would definitely recommend the game."
helpfulPercent: 20 of 20 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
There are no negative reviews right now, and Im assuming that's because a lot of the reviews come from people who got the game for free at PAX or something such as myself. I don't think this is a 100% pass, so just check out my pros and cons.

Pros:
-Nice basic graphics
-Interesting looking world
-Pretty simple, feels very zen
-Music is good
-Some puzzles that make you think

Cons:
-VERY short, finished in under an hour and I wasn't rushing at all
-$10 is too much for a game that you can finish in under an hour
-Story was pretty weak, was hoping for a little more since the gameplay was so simple
-Feels like a fleshed out flash game, would expect more from the number of people who worked on it as shown in the credits.

If you like to replay simple games I think this game could be worth it at maybe $5, but for me personally I will probably never touch it again and would be very dissapointed if I had actually bought it for $10. I think a longer campaign, slightly better story, and puzzles that scale in difficulty would make this game much better.

(sidenote: met some of the developers of the game at PAX, they were very nice people and generous enough to hand out there game for free.)

reviewText:
Beautiful yet mysterious game.
I really enjoyed this game! You are a robot who travels through a planet trying to find your purpose and survive the obstacles throughout the way.  I loved the art style and music. Different areas in the game are very vivid with colors and then once you go into the caves they are more darker yet still beautiful. The atmosphere almost has a curious, mysterious feeling to it too. I also noticed in each different area, new music would play.

The puzzles are fun and tricky and really make you think outside the box. The controls are very smooth as well, they did an excellent job with that. The plot was lovely, it was dispersed nicely. Throughout the game, you pick up casettes. These were left by the man who created you. He talks briefly about his journey and scientists that helped to create you.  But the game speaks for itself; it's one of those games where it's simple and there's not a lot of dialogue yet it's so intriguing.

reviewText: The silent little robot may be the player character, but the real star of the game is the strange planet and the angular art style its rendered in. In fact, the quickest and easiest comparison would be Limbo, which was another game that divided its attention between a moody art style and platforming action.\n\nIt may be short-lived (~60 mins: curse on you if you decide to refund it after finishing it) and a little rough around the edges here and there, but Planet of the Eyes is a game that balances just the right level of challenge with story to create a decent experience for players looking for a quick fix. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=567624555 http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=571415579 Unlocked all achievements!
voteText: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful

reviewerDisplayName: T R A V E X X
reviewText:
Planet of the Eyes is a stellar platformer with a ominous storyline. The ambiance of the landscape really draws you in with it's simple, yet stunning art. The game is short but sweet, telling a small story and not much more.

The platforming itself started out very simple; however, as the game progresses so did the difficulty. Fun mechanics with and small inovations in platforming can be found throughout the game. As you can expect from any platformer there are a variety of small puzzles to complete to achieve victory.

I rate the game with a 8/10 and here is a list of my Pros and Cons of the game:

Pros:
-Stunning Graphics
-Great Story
-Fun Mechanics
-Short and Sweet(Can be a con to some)
-Great Music

Cons:
-Very Easy(Can be a pro to some)
-Few bugs although not game breaking
-Repetition in game mechanics/puzzles

Overall I would recommend this game to any platforming fan. I have made a full playthrough to anyone who is curious about the game.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mzfCDWa_Ah8&list=PLPfCUUTvwrsCrF0rPiPeq-FoTijrl-9pd
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Planet of the Eyes is a pretty good game. Everything in the game has been created in service of the atmosphere, which is Planet of the Eyes’ biggest strength. It’s a relaxing puzzle-platformer with a creepy edge to it with puzzles that, while not overly challenging, are generally fun to complete. It’s also a fantastic game to look at with a superb, eye-catching art style and excellent sound design. Even though the main story generally falls flat, it’s still a fairly compelling game whose expertly crafted atmosphere will suck you in and keep you playing to the very end. While Planet of the Eyes isn’t an earth shatteringly amazing game, it is a good one, and it achieves much of what it sets out to achieve.

Full review:

http://wordsaboutgames.net/2015/08/24/planet-of-the-eyes-review/
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: This is a very short game. I completed it in about an hour and a half. The story was alright, it seemed a bit stopped short for the potential it had. Also, the gameplay is very basic platforming, however a few endgame jumps seemed a bit finnicky. The graphics were very good, and the music was very zen, almost putting me into a trance like state while playing. Some people believe a game needs to give you 8-10+ hours for a $10 game. This game is not for them. If you are like me an appreciate a game that understands your time is precious and gives you just enough gamplay to not be overly repetitive and to tell whatever story it wants to tell, this is the game for you. It is worth the buy as long as you aren't expecting a long game or some unique platformer.

reviewText: The first video game I've played in years and it's exactly what I wanted. A totally immersive platforming experience from start to finish. The art is simple yet elegant in its design, with a wonderful soundtrack that pulls you into the mysterious cosmic world of our little hero. Was planning on taking my time with it but the gameplay was so enthralling I ended up finishing it in a few hours. There are a few challenging puzzles, but likely won't leave you banging your head against the wall trying to solve. For those who are fans of Cave Story (incidentally the last game I played many moons back), you're in for a treat!

reviewText: Planet of The Eyes is a story-driven puzzle-platformer that's very reminiscent of Limbo. The bright colorscheme, awesome soundtrack and unique story in Plaet of The Eyes do more than enough to set them apart, though. I'm about 75% through the game at this point, and none of the puzzles have stumped me to the point where I have to look up the answers, which is great considering the story, voice acting and writing are good enough to make you want to get to the next point in the story as quick as you can.\n\nWhether you get it for $7.99 or $9.99, Planet of The Eyes is a steal. I can't recommend it enough.

reviewText: Really solid puzzle-platformer. Planet of the Eyes has a refreshingly bright colour palette and great artistic style. The story is told though audio logs which are well written and voiced and I grew very attached to my little explorer robot. The gameplay focuses on puzzle solving and platforming that requires good timing. I died a lot, but never felt punished for it. There's an achievement for most types of death, the checkpoints are generous, and there are practically no load times.

reviewText:
It's OK. It falls just short of a positive recommendation, so instead I'll say pick it up during a sale.

Pros:
-Decent voice acting.
-Nice music.
-Uncapped frame rate.
-Great aesthetic.
-Adequate controls, not the best but good enough.

Cons:
-Kinda boring with long stretches of running with no meaningful obstacles.
-Cannot view, let alone rebind keys. Granted there are only 2 meaningful actions (jump and grab/interact), still a con.
-Kinda short for it's asking price.
-Sometimes it's hard to tell whats foreground, background or middle ground. Foreground objects are sometimes the same color as middle ground.
-The story is mediocre, it's like they want to make you feel for a character you have no reason to feel for.

reviewText: I finished the entire game in 90 minutes and am looking forward to play it again. I cannot see, however, how anyone would take up to 5 hours to complete the game (as per the game's description). I imagine some will be able to blaze through in an hour, but that most people will take a couple of hours at most to finish it. That's fine, though. I like the fact that the developers have chosen to go for quality over quantity: a lot of games tend to outstay their welcome!\n\nThe puzzles are simple yet fun, the platforming is never a chore, and the atmosphere is second to none. The visuals are great and the audio is just as good. One or two minor complaints: sometimes the little robot had a tendency to skid a bit and the controls, while generally fine, occasionally felt less precise than I would have wanted, making jumping on small platforms a little trickier than should really be necessary. But really, those are minor complaints and I thoroughly recommend you buy this.

reviewText: I was introduced to Planet of the Eyes in Seattle at PAX2015. This was one of the games that stuck in my mind over the 4 days at the convention. When leaving the booth, I made sure to snag a business card, and with it came a free game key! This game is truly priceless. The visuals are perfectly simple, yet stunning and they transition smoothly when you enter new areas - you almost don't notice that your environment has just changed! I love the sound design - the music and ambient sound are really mood-setting. The 2D/3D feel is smooth, and the controls are very user-friendly. The puzzles are very reminiscent of LIMBO, but are independently challenging and I heavilty recommend this game if you love games that make you stop and think, while charming you at the same time, like Portal and The Talos Principle.\n\nI immediately fell in love with the little robot, and you will find yourself excitedly anticipating finding the next cassette with clues as to who made you, and what happened to lead you to this strange planet. I haven't finished the game yet, and while I dread the moment it's over, I am excited to jump back in today and become reacquatinted with my little robo buddy <3

reviewText:
Planet of the Eyes - A Steam Review
[Disclamer - I was provided a copy of by the publisher for review purposes]

The good
Beautiful graphical style
Engaging story
Interesting puzzles
The not so good:
It was over too fast, but that’s more of a measure of the fact that I enjoyed it a lot
The conclusion:
I started playing this game admiring the art style and ended up finishing it in one sitting. It’s like a perfect lovechild between Limbo and OIO, another indie platformer about a robot, that unfortunately is not available on Steam. Anyway, I really struggled to find anything at fault with this game. The story is interesting, the puzzle mechanics are great and I guarantee that once you start it, you won’t be able to put it down until it’s over. Loved the minecart mechanics.
You can see me playing it here - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-e4DFuEIs5w
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A non-biased quick look @ the game:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tt3rfVpJF7s

A fantastic art style and wondeful set locations sets this platform out from many other indie titles. You’ve crash-landed on the Planet of the Eyes in an escape pod. Discover what lies beneath through puzzle solving, exploration, and audiologs from another survivor. Turn down the lights, put on your headphones and grab your controller to experience the atmospheric journey of a lone robot in a dangerous world.

Planet of the Eyes will keep you on the edge and test your platforming skill. With quick respawns upon death and physics-based puzzles to solve, there is a mix of challenges that rewards experimentation. - Highly Recommended!

reviewText: Fantastic platformer. The game combines simple puzzles and platformer skill in a seemless way. Visually, this game does not dissapoint. The art style is very pleasing, and fits the over all atmosphere very well. The soundtrack is very pleasing to listen to, and does a wonderful job establishing the atmosphere. The only problem I had with the game is that is is fairly short. It took me roughly 2 hours to play, but I would imagine it would take most people around 3, I happened to have somebody watching to help with the puzzles.\n\nOverall, a great game. Well worth buying.

reviewText:
Such a sweet, short game.

Folks who enjoyed Out of This World or Limbo will probably find this worth a look. Even though it's not as involved on either the storytelling or gameplay fronts given the brevity, it does manage to tell an engaging tale within that span. The platforming mechanics are effectively used, and the puzzles, though easy, are varied and paced well such the game flows well in a single sitting playthrough.

I hope this game does well for Cococucumber so that they can pursue more ambitious projects in the future!
